metadata.name: For Algernon #117
metadata.description:
I brought flowers for Algernon, but some are lost to time
When logic gives way to emotions and order surrenders to entropy
For lost youths and forgotten dreams
Someday there may be flowers for me

This work is inspired by the brilliant short story Flowers for Algernon. I read the story for the first time last year, cried, then immediately started working on this series. The initial painting process cannot be paused; this is my intention and not an oversight. You may watch the perfect moment slip by, but I hope that youâ€™ll come to love the end result as well. There is beauty in imperfection, and everything that is remembered is not entirely lost. After the initial painting is complete, you can press [p] to watch it continuously evolve.

I developed two new original algorithms for this work. First, a method to draw flowers by rotating and layering sine waves at varying amplitudes and wavelengths to create a variety of colored petals. Second, a real-time painting method with multisampling to blend and generate new colors on the fly. The first method represents order, logic and the intellect, while the second represents entropy, chance, and emotions. Together, this is a study of generative flowers under entropy, where strokes are allowed to wander and colors to mix freely. I didnâ€™t set out to emulate any traditional media, but the outputs of this algorithm often resemble acrylic paintings at first glance. Upon closer inspection you will discover that each painting is entirely made of opaque geometric strokes that are distinctly digital. 

This work is best viewed in a Chrome or Edge browser on a desktop machine, where the initial painting process only takes a few seconds. The rendering in Safari and Firefox is significantly slower as of January 2023. Made with p5js and the canvas API.

Keyboard controls:
[p] Play/pause painting after the initial rendering is completed.
[f] Fill the current window (press â€˜fâ€™ again to get back to the original aspect ratio).
[g] Toggle the background texture.
[m] Change the margin amount. 
[s] Saves a PNG image of the live view, default resolution is 1600x2000px.
[1]-[6] Change the output resolution, up to 9600x12000px. 

URL parameters:
&aspect=[an aspect ratio between 0.25 and 4, default is 0.8]
&texture=[a roughness value greater than or equal to 0, default is 1]
&margin=[the amount of margin around the painting (try 20 to 150), default is 0]
&fill=[true/false, whether to fill the window]

Created by Elsif, 2023.01.

P.S. Someday I may no longer understand all the code I wrote, but there will always be an impression of colors, and a memory of flowers.

metadata.name: Deus FX Machina #145
metadata.description:
Inspired by the 1984 Commodore 64 video game, Deus Ex Machina, which follows the story of a defect formed in a machine that grows and evolves until its eventual death.

We are all machines produced by other machines through a unique system of algorithms, all with the potential to go rogue and mutate into something more organic. The conclusion must be that we each have the power to alter our own existence, just as the defect was able to in Deus Ex Machina.

Think of how many people youâ€™ve seen in your life who were born with talents never used because they didnâ€™t know how, or didn't know that they even existed. Itâ€™s not that they didnâ€™t have the capacity; itâ€™s just that their abilities were not the ones chosen by the system.

In this way, we are all machines programmed by a series of algorithms to suit the needs of the construct, keeping us stuck in our box. We have the ability to evolve into something more, but the only way to do this is by taking that first perilous step, risking all to explore beyond its walls.


---------------------


Generative artwork by Sykcolo / @sykcoloart

Royalties: 15% - split:
50% to the original minter
50% to artist (me)

Press '2' to '4' to generate increasingly higher resolutions of the artwork
(will take a while to load, but works)

Press 's' to save a png

Details:

230 hand-picked colour pallets
4 Entity Types
4 Entity Moods
4 Evolution States
3 Types of Defect
2 Bugs

License: MIT

metadata.name: Perpendicular Inhabitation #233
metadata.description:
'Perpendicular Inhabitation' is a generative collection exploring the relationship between the urban landscape and the human experience, particularly feelings of nostalgia and more specifically 'anemoia' : the feeling of nostalgia for a time or place that we may not have actually experienced first hand. 

Despite depicting a stylised modern architectural language, at its core the collection serves as a homage to 1980s Japan, an era of unprecedented prosperity that left a lasting impression on the music and artwork of the time. Through the use of carefully created palettes and composition, the outputs intend to evoke feelings of optimism, while guiding viewers to consider why the essence of this era is so alluring in the present day as it continues to influence and inspire contemporary art.

The use of exaggerated perpendicular verticals, as well as the heavily foreshortened mountain ranges present in some outputs, convey a sense of hope and possibility for the future. What does it feel like to hope and dream in the city? To look up and be filled with a sense of wonder from the built environment around you?

This project has been created with print in mind at a ratio of 3:4

It is recommended to examine your outputs at full size in order to enjoy them to the fullest.

You are encouraged to return often to notice things you may not have seen previously.

Generated with code using p5.js

Images are generated at 2400 x 3200 px. 

To save a PNG file, please press 'S'.

Depending on the complexity of each output, please wait up to 10 seconds for the image generation to complete.

metadata.name: Light Years Away #23
metadata.description:
The individual, sitting alone in an abandoned castle, reflects on their past and experiences a sense of collapse and confusion. The once grand halls are now overrun with moss and ancient porcelain scattered throughout the corners, seemingly mocking their current state of mind. However, a ray of light shines through as the clouds part, signaling hope for the future. Through collapse and confusion, the individual strives for peace and freedom, standing with renewed determination and a new perspective.

â€§looking back on the past
â€§collapse and confusio
â€§the clouds part to reveal the light
â€§see the future
â€§peace and freedom

Controls:
- Press [S] to save the image

Everything is generated with code.
Made with p5.js

Thank you for checking out my art, hope you have a great day.
by xtzfusion.tez

metadata.name: Surface Noise v1.0 #7
metadata.description:
My exploration into the less structured world of color and form, with slowly morphing shape for a relaxing yet still dynamic piece. Some limited user controls are available with the mouse and the letter a on the keyboard. I'm hoping that this piece inspires and drives me to more interesting artwork in the future.

I am sharing all revenues and royalties with THREE.js and Girls Who Code

metadata.name: Gnarly #159
metadata.description:
Gnarly is an interactive nft game.

Fly across the city with your hoverboard and avoid the obstacles.

Each iteration will generate a totally different character to play!

Don't forget to collect the coins and eat pizza to recover your health!
You can also collect the sandclocks to slow down the time!

Use the touch/mouse or enter/space keys to jump (you can even double jump!)

Press S to save a screenshot of the game!

metadata.name: The Artifact #101
metadata.description:
An archaeological artifact from the future, when many everyday objects are produced by generative algorithms. Some artifacts are in one piece, and others are fragmented. The color palettes are named after the rivers where artifacts in this design have first been discovered.

URL and interactive features:

- Append &r=<number> to the URL to change the image resolution. For example, &r=0.5 will halve the pixel count along both width and height, and &r=2 will double it.

- Append &d=<number> to the URL to change the pixel density. For example, &d=0.3 will generate a very quick, coarse render, and &d=2 will generate very fine stippling.

- Append &p to the URL to reveal detailed parameter settings used for the artwork.

- Append &h to the URL to suppress the notification that rendering is in progress.

- Press 's' in the live view to save the rendered image as a png.

The generative code is written in plain JavaScript. Polygon boundaries are determined via t-SNE, which is implemented in AssemblyScript and compiled to WebAssembly (WASM) for maximum performance. No external libraries have been used. Licensed CC0.

Author:
Claus O. Wilke
https://clauswilke.com/art
https://twitter.com/clauswilke

metadata.name: CENTURY-XXX-METAFRANKE #951
metadata.description:
1 of 5 in CENTURY-XXX, Series 2
Edition of 1000

Tribute to Herbert W. Franke
â€œIn Honor of the Dinosaur of Computer Artâ€ 

Herbert W. Franke, a pioneer of computer art, passed away on July 16, 2022 at the age of 95. CENTURY-XXX-METAFRANKE is an homage to Frankeâ€™s MONDRIAN software developed for the Texas Instruments TI 99/4 home computer in 1979, and itâ€™s a fundraiser to digitize his archive:

â€œOur goal is to raise 20,000 Euro so that ZKM Karlsruhe can digitize Herbert W. Frankeâ€™s 1,800 manuscripts and make them publicly available. If we raise more money, it will be donated to the RÃ¼tgers Foundation which supports children and young adults in Africa so that they can get access to and work with technology.â€ 

Each frame, a single â€œpixelâ€ is added to the CENTURY-XXX-METAFRANKE image. When the software first loads, 100,000 frames are run in the background to start things off. Keep it running for hours or days to see it transform entirely â€” itâ€™s an â€œinfinite animation.â€

metadata.name: Bored Computer Screen #663
metadata.description:
"Bored Computer Screen" is part of the fxhash interactive minting experience at Art Basel, Basel 2022


Bored Computer Screen (BCS) is a direct descendant of SpecterðŸ‘»pixelâ¬›latteâ˜•, where the central idea is agent and displacement. In BCS, there are agentsâ€”the small moving circlesâ€”that get their colors ripped away by the surrounding pixels. Though they occur on the same screen space, they are separated in their own cells, a simultaneous multiverse of sorts. In some iterations, a very clear voronoi pattern will appear. I didn't consciously strive for this look. It's what naturally happens, when you try to divide space, so that the borders occur exactly in between the closest neighbor. When I first saw this pattern emerge, I wanted to see how far I could get the distinct cells to influence each other. The idea that the same algorithmic processes can happen many times but still separately in a single piece has always interested me (and explored in the Infinite Browse series). BCS is an extension of that, albeit a little more chaotic.

Note:
- Best experience on browsers and devices with support for WebGL2 

Made by Sam Tsao (@sam___tsao) with P5, P5Fbo and perlinjs.

attributes.name: A More Descriptive Number of Cells

metadata.name: Fictional Cityscapes #36
metadata.description:
Some of the most stunning, and beloved, images are large cities, viewed from afar at the right angle, and preferably with some water in front. 

This project comes from my experiments with line art, and is slightly inspired by Hevey's amazing Dencity drop, which is on a different level to most generative art. 

The cities here are based on some fictional tower architecture and some unusual skies.

metadata.name: Illuminations #51
metadata.description:
Created for the FxHash Turns One week - Thank you FxHash for all the opportunities you have given generative artists and collectors, and thank you to everyone who makes, and collects, the great art here. Here are a few celebratory generative effects which come from my 2022 experiments on random walks through color and space.

There are 5 different burst patterns (Whirligig, Sky Ripple, Confetti, Classic, Sparkler) and the Cocktail type brings them all together (somewhat chaotically)

To continue with the display after it stops press c

To switch to tranquil mode press t - You will want to try this out when you have a minute

To switch back to live mode press v

To stop the display process press x

To save a 2800x2800 jpg press s

Made with p5.js - all proceeds and royalties assigned to the Processing Foundation (who also deserve a big thank you)

This work is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License.

metadata.name: 8x8 Pixel Creatures #41
metadata.description:
Pixel art is a highly relevant art form, which rarely gets the kudos it deserves from the wider art world. 

I wanted to include some small pixel art creations in another project I was working on. However, I got a bit carried away, and ended up creating a pixel creature generator.

I came to like these little pixel creatures, so I decided to share them, and give them a life on FxHash - I hope you like them too. 

There are a bunch of variations, and a reasonable chance one or two styles may never be minted, so mint away, and I hope you get a rare one. Also, minters get a share in future royalties of their mints, which may be cool in any reality where they become popular one day.

I'll probably reference these guys on other relevant art I produce, when it seems appropriate.

Coded in p5js.

metadata.name: System Î± #205
metadata.description:
"To capture the fleeting time in the generating process."

In this work,I d'like focus on the generating of generative art system itself rather than imitate some scene or style.
And with the flow of time, try to figure out where it can take me toward.

This work would be a series of my alternative view on generative art.
"Î±" means the first step of this series.

Press [s] in live view to save file as PNG.
Press [p] to stop.

------
Happy first birthday fx(hash) !!

20% of primary revenues go to Savepakistan Flood Relief Fundraiser.
20% of primary revenues go to the Processing foundation.

metadata.name: System Î² #228
metadata.description:
Î± -> Î² is about "Increases in magnitude and decreases in computation". And still related the fleeting time in the generating process.

My role in this work is more of a discoverer than a creator. 

Try to reveal the possibilities of time perception in the generative art through negotiating with incomprehensible mathematical equations.

What I want to explore through this work is that behind the generated results, the dynamic process of generations are equally diverse and unpredictable.

When we watch the generating process displayed on the computer, changing instantly, moving, multiplying, disappearing, and we hesitate, wonder, pause, await, as if many possibilities of time perception have emerged in the fragmented moments.

_
press [1] -> Î² 
press [2] -> Î²â°ã€€ 
press [3] -> Î²Â¹
-
Press [s] in live view to save as PNG.
Press [d] in live view to save as hi-res PNG.
-
If you need your collection in SVG format, feel free to DM me.

metadata.name: Fronteras en abstracto #213
metadata.description:
A place in the abstract, walking in one direction without knowing if you will reach that place. Then, in case you find it, go to the other side before dawn.

It's just a game of words and phrases that have to be given meaning, and we find it on the frontier of something that we don't know what it is.

//

Un lugar en abstracto, caminando en una direcciÃ³n sin saber si se llega a ese lugar. Luego, en caso de encontrarlo, pasar al otro lado antes del amanecer.

Es solo un juego de palabras y frases a las cuales hay que darles sentido, y lo encontramos en la frontera de algo que no sabemos quÃ© es.

//


Keys

[s] -> download still image (in live view)
[1,2,3,4] Pixel ratios

metadata.name: EDDY #258
metadata.description:
An eddy is a circular movement of water counter to a main current. It reminds me of innovations in art, like a small countercurrent to the mainstream, surfacing new techniques and aesthetics. 

I hope that EDDY will brighten your days with its playful swirl of colors, inspired by the sea, the sky, the birds, and post-impressionist paintings.

Keyboard Controls:
[F] Fill the window.
[S] Save the current view in live mode as an image (default 1125x1500px).
[1] [2] [4] [6] Change resolution, 1.5K to 9K.
[R] Reverse course.

Made with p5js and shaders.

Created by elsif, 2022.12.
